plant_concentrations.References: (1) Salamova A, Hites RA; Environ Sci Technol 47: 349-54 (2013)
plant_concentrations.Value: Tree bark collected from 12 locations around the globe in 2009-2010 contained hexabromocyclododecane concentrations ranging from 0.27-21.3 ng/g lipid weight with concentrations associated with human population in the near-by areas(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Jaspers V et al; Environ Pollut 136: 81-88 (2005) (2) Lindberg P et al; Environ Sci Technol 38: 93-96 (2004) (3) Sellstrom U et al; Environ Sci Technol 37: 5496-501 (2003) (4) Bustnes JO et al; Environ Sci Technol 41(24): 8491-97 (2007)
animal_concentrations.Value: Hexabromocyclododecane concentrations in two of 40 eggs of Little Owls (Athene noctua) in Belgium were 20 and 50 ng/g lipid(1). Concentrations found in eggs of Peregrine Falcons (Falco peregrinus) breeding in Sweden were 150 and 250 ng/g lipid weight for northern and southern wild populations, respectively; it was not detected in eggs of captive falcons(2). Levels in Guillemot eggs (Uria algae) from the Baltic Sea were sampled between 1969 and 2001(3). Beginning with 1969 at 78 ng/g lipid weight, concentrations peaked in the mid-1970s at 150 ng/g lipid weight) followed by a decrease (34 ng/g lipid weight in 1981), and then increased in the late-1980s to 130 ng/g lipid weight, remaining stable at a higher level thereafter, 110-170 ng/g lipid weight(3). Mean hexabromocyclododecane concentration in Tawny Owl (Strix aluco) eggs collected from central Norway between 1986-1989 and 2001-2004 was 6.35 and 2.07 ng/g lipid weight(4).
Hexabromocyclododecane in 43 unhatched bird eggs of 8 South African species, sampled from November 2004 to March 2005(1).

animal_concentrations.References: ECHA; European Chemicals Agency. Risk Assessment: Hexabromocyclododecane (25637-99-4) May 2008. Available from, as of Mar 26, 2015: https://esis.jrc.ec.europa.eu/
animal_concentrations.Value: ... The total-HBCDD levels in blubber of female harbor porpoises (Phocoena phocoena) and common dolphins (Delphinus delphis) stranded on Western European coasts between Scotland (UK) and Galicia in Spain /were investigated/ by GC/MS. The isomeric composition of HBCDD in blubber was investigated by LC/MS in a selection of 19 samples, representing all sampling areas. The possible influence of cytochrome P450 mediated biotransformation on the changes in the isomer composition (alpha-, beta- and gamma-HBCD) in the residues in blubber with respect to the commercial mixture was investigated by in vitro assays with hepatic microsomes of rat and harbor seal (Phoca vitulina). All the 19 samples (10 harbor porpoises and 9 common dolphins) contained exclusively the alpha-diastereomer, despite the dominance of the gamma-diastereomer in commercial mixtures. In the four replicate preparations of (phenobarbital induced) rat microsomes and an artificial 1:1:1 mixture of the three diastereomers, the peaks of the beta- and gamma-diastereomers of HBCDD showed a highly significant decrease, but the peak of the alpha-diastereomer had not become significantly smaller even after 90 minutes incubation at 37 °C. In the 90-minutes incubation with harbor seal microsomes, the beta- and gamma-diastereomer seemed to decrease, whereas no significant disappearance of alpha-HBCDD was observed. For beta-HBCD, three bromine-containing metabolites could be observed, while for gamma-HBCDD two such metabolites were observed. Hydroxy-metabolites of both the beta-diastereomer and gamma-diastereomer were found.

Concentrations of tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) and alpha-, beta-, and gamma-isomers of hexabromocyclododecanes (HBCDs) were determined by liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-ESI-MS/MS) in... /a/ marine top-level predator--bottlenose dolphin--collected from coastal waters of Florida, USA. The overall mean concentrations (mean+/-SD) of TBBPA and HBCDs were 1.2+/-3 and 7.38+/-18 ng/g lipid wt in bottlenose dolphin blubber. Overall mean concentrations of HBCDs were 5-10-fold higher than mean TBBPA concentrations, in all of the samples analyzed. ... HBCD concentrations in bottlenose dolphins from the United States were 1-2 orders of magnitude lower than the concentrations reported for other cetacean species from Europe.

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Eljarrat E et al; Environ Sci Technol 38: 2603-8 (2004) (2) Sellstrom U et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 17: 1065-72 (1998) (3) Tomy GT et al; Environ Sci Technol 38: 2298-303 (2004)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Hexabromocyclododecane concentrations ranged from not detected (detection limits in the range of 2-19 pg/g wet weight) to 1,172 ng/g wet weight in 23 fish samples (Barbus graellsi) from the Cinca River (tributary to the Ebro River, Spain) collected in the vicinity of the heavily industrialized area of Monzon(1). Fish samples from the Swedish River Viskin, sampled in 1995 and collected up and downstream from textile industries, contained hexabromocyclododecane at concentrations ranging from <80 ng/g lipid weight (upstream) to 8,000 ng/g lipid weight (downstream)(2). A concentration of <90 ng/g lipid weight was detected in fish from Lake Skaresjon, a parallel water system(2). Upon analysis of the Lake Ontario pelagic food web, it was found that concentrations of the alpha-isomer were higher than the gamma-isomer, with beta-hexabromocyclododecane being below the detection limit of 30 pg/g wet weight(3). Mean alpha-isomer level in plankton was 0.03 ng/g wet weight; mean gamma-isomer level in Mysis was 0.01 ng/g wet weight(3). Levels in forage fish were 0.005 and 0.05 (alewife); 0.05 and 0.4 (sculpin); 0.07 and 0.25 (smelt); levels in a top predator were 1.5 and 0.4 ng/g wet weight (lake trout) for alpha- and gamma-isomers, respectively(3).

A monitoring study comparing results from up to 13 laboratories found mean 1,2,5,6,9,10-hexabromocyclododecane concentrations (in pg/g fresh weight) in the following seafoods: cod liver oil, 7039; herring fillet, 399; salmon fillet, 284(1).

fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Concentrations of tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) and alpha-, beta-, and gamma-isomers of hexabromocyclododecanes (HBCDs) were determined by liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-ESI-MS/MS) in .. marine top-level predators ... bull shark, and Atlantic sharpnose shark--collected from coastal waters of Florida, USA. The overall mean concentrations (mean+/-SD) of TBBPA and HBCDs were ... 9.5+/-12 and 77.7+/-128 ng/g lipid wt in bull shark muscle, and 0.872+/-0.5 and 54.5+/-88 ng/g lipid wt in Atlantic sharpnose shark muscle. Overall mean concentrations of HBCDs were 5-10-fold higher than mean TBBPA concentrations, in all of the samples analyzed. The highest concentrations of TBBPA and HBCDs were detected in the bull shark muscle at concentrations of 35.6 and 413 ng/g, lipid wt, respectively.

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Eljarrat E et al; Environ Sci Technol 38: 2603-8 (2004) (2) Sellstrom U et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 17: 1065-72 (1998) (3) Bogdal C et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 6817-22 (2008) (4) Ramu K et al; Chemosphere 79: 713-9 (2010) (5) Yang R et al; Environ Sci Technol 46: 3119-26 (2012)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Hexabromocyclododecane concentrations ranged from not detected (detection limit in the range of 6-50 pg/g dry weight) to 514 ng/g dry weight in sediments from the Cinca River (tributary to the Ebro River, Spain) collected in the vicinity of the heavily industrialized area of Monzon(1). Sediment samples from the Swedish River Viskin, sampled in 1995 and collected up and downstream from textile industries, contained hexabromocyclododecane at concentrations ranging from <0.9 ng/g (upstream) to 7,000 ng/g (downstream)(2). A concentration of <1.0 ng/g was detected in sediment from Lake Skaresjon, a parallel water system(2). A concentration of <1.0 ng/g was detected in sediment from Lake Skaresjon, a parallel water system(2). Three dated sediment cores from a prealpine lake, Lake Thun, in Switzerland revealed that hexabromocyclododecane concentrations started to increase in the 1980s through the 1990s with a decrease observed in one core more recently(3). Surface sediments collected from 24 coastal locations in Korea in 2005 contained hexabromocyclododecane concentrations of 0.39-0.59 ng/g dry wt(4). Hexabromocyclododecane was detected in sediment cores collected from the Great Lakes in August 2007 at concentration range of 0.04-3.1 ng/g dry weight(5).
